text:
HUBERT DANSO: I think
the greatest opportunity

the continent has is outreach
to colleagues in the diaspora

and, I'd build onto that,
descendants of colleagues

in the diaspora because I think
there's a huge pool of talent

and expertise that we're not
taking full advantage of.

I don't even think we're
scratching the surface.

I think we are looking
at it from a very--

or through a very
developmental lens.

And I don't think it's a
developmental opportunity.

I think it's a real
business opportunity

to start, effectively, onshoring
a lot of your best talent

to grow your economy and
pursue your economic goals.

And there are a
lot of new models

that I'm not hearing
when people talk

about diaspora
returning, which are just
simple principles of business--

the extent to which you
know your local market,

the extent to which you
have good local partners,

and the extent to which you
have good technical expertise
and systems.

And I think the
diaspora are very

well-placed to better
understand the local risk

and bring companies and
capital and partners

back to the continent
and grow businesses.

If you look at some
of the young men,

some of the new billionaires
in the continent--

are ones that have been
raising a lot of their money
on the London Stock Exchange.

And in many respects, their
peers in the continent

probably have a lot more
exposure and understanding
of that market and opportunity.

But they don't have the
intellectual capital and access
to the international markets.

And I think the
two need to coexist

and both leverage
those opportunities.

And I think that's the
model that can certainly

catapult the growth of some
key industries in Africa.

We're seeing it with the
likes of Oando in Nigeria.

It's grown to be a
multibillion-dollar company.

We see some MIT grads and
some Harvard grads going back

into East Africa, setting
up very well-structured,

effective, growth-oriented,
pan-African ICT and consumer

play businesses that
are very exciting--

the same in the
oil and gas sector,

coming with some great
expertise and some good capital,

building out some of the
logistics terminals and ports,

being able to look to
the future and being

able to take that medium to
long-term growth opportunity
and structure it and bank it.

And I think that's what
I see in the diaspora.

The brain gain is a natural
consequence of that.

So I think that
for us, that model
is really what's exciting.
